data.text: VOLUME 131 - NO. 42 THURSDAY, MAY 27, 2010 DECATUR, TEXAS 56 PAGES IN THREE SECTIONS PLUS INSERTS 75¢ DECATUR BRIDGEPORT City probe leads to firings By MANDY BOURGEOIS Messenger photo by Johnny Britton MINI BULL RUN — The mini bull riders had a better night than most of the professionals at J.W. Hart PBR Challenge in Decatur Saturday. Boudreaux Campbell, 11, of Plantersville, held on to finish third in the event. Bull speed ahead Riders found quite a challenge at J.W. Hart PBR By BRANDON EVANS Aaron Pass, 21, of Hillsboro held on through two rough rounds to clench first place overall in the seventh annual J.W. Hart PBR at the Wise County Sheriff’s Posse Arena in Decatur. The bulls proved tougher than most of the riders Saturday night. After cycling through 47 riders, only eight managed to score. Cloven hooves danced dangerously across the sand as the bulls spun like whirling dervishes. The 1,500 pound behemoths bucked off the rugged riders again and again. “They brought in some tough bulls,” said Andrew Rottner, one of the event coordinators. Riding Mr. Personality, Pass scored 82 in the first round, putting him in seventh. Douglas Duncan, 23, of Alvin won the first round with a score of 88. Pass sealed the win with a score of 91 in the championship round taking home purse of $4,568.20 for 16 seconds of work. Pass is currently ranked 53rd in the world. Mike Lee, 26, of Decatur, was the only local in Saturday’s PBR. Lee, one of the top 10 riders in the world, failed to score. A chocolate-colored bull named Lil Red Cat tossed him into the red dirt right out of the chute. “I just got a bad start,” Lee said. “Somehow my foot ended up on the back of his neck, and that’s never a good way to start.” WISE COUNTY Fire consumes vacant mobile home By BRANDON EVANS A fire destroyed a mobile home in the 100 block of righton Oaks Drive Monday afternoon in southern ise County. Boyd, Rhome and Newark fire departments reponded, but the home burned quickly in the afteroon heat. A man was burning brush on his family’s property hen the fire skipped to a trailer home several feet way. The home was uninhabited, and no one was injured. “My son put some livestock in here and was trying to burn some brush,” said Tim Bradberry, who owns the property. “He walked away for a minute, and all of a sudden flames were coming out of the home.” His son, Jimmy Lee Bradberry, uses the land to Continued on page 2A Continued on page 4A COOLING DOWN — Matt Germain with the Rhome Volunteer Fire Department takes a splash from the hose while fighting a structure fire just north of Briar in the blistering heat Monday afternoon. Messenger photo by Andrew May The city of Bridgeport has terminated employees following an internal investigation. According to a press release sent to the Wise County Messenger Monday evening, the city of Bridgeport launched an internal investigation May 19 when instances of city employee misconduct were brought to light. “We had some improprieties going on that we discovered, and we turned it over to the police department,” said Mayor Keith McComis. “There were some employees terminated, and some employees we put on leave.” McComis said that because the investigation is ongoing, he was unable to provide more information. NORTHWEST Gindt hired by Northwest By BRIAN KNOX While the Decatur School Board has begun its search for the next superintendent, the outgoing superintendent has found a new job, and it’s not too far away. Gary Gindt was named assistant superintendent for administrative services at the Northwest school district Monday. He will GINDT replace Mona Benotti, who is retiring at the end of the school year. Gindt announced his resignation from Decatur in March to be effective June 30. In his new position, Gindt will oversee Northwest’s human resources division, safety and security department, technology infrastructure and the contracted food services program and print shop. Gindt said the district’s reputation for excellence drew him to the school. “I was interested from the standpoint that the district’s been very successful in everything they’ve done, whether it’s academics or planning for growth. Everything is first-class,” he said.
